case_vignette: A 1-year-old male presents with intermittent history of itchy spots on the palms and soles that flare and then resolve over the past 6 months. Mother is unable to identify any clear inciting trigger. She has tried over the counter hydrocortisone but lesions remain. An in office mineral oil preparation is negative for any microorganisms. Physical examination reveals vesiculopustules over the palms, soles, and ankles.   The patient is otherwise healthy and has no significant past medical history. The patient is up to date on all vaccinations. The patient is afebrile and has no other symptoms. The patient's mother reports that the patient has been experiencing these symptoms for 6 months and has been to the pediatrician multiple times for evaluation. The patient's mother is concerned that the patient may have eczema or another skin condition. The patient's mother is also concerned that the patient may have a food allergy. The patient's mother reports that the patient has been eating a variety of foods and has not had any other symptoms besides the itchy spots. The patient's mother is concerned that the patient may have a skin condition that is not responding to treatment. The patient's mother is also concerned that the patient may have a food allergy that is causing the symptoms. The patient's mother is concerned that the patient may have a skin condition that is not responding to treatment and is worried that the patient may have a food allergy. question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have itchy spots on my palms and soles.
Have these spots spread to other parts of your body?
Yes, they have also spread to my ankles.
What is the appearance of these spots? Are they red, scaly, pus-filled, or blister-like?
The spots are vesiculopustules, which means they are blister-like with some pus.
Have you recently had any fever, sore throat, or other symptoms of infection?
No, I have not had a fever or any other symptoms of infection.
Do you have any known allergies or have you started using any new products that come into contact with your skin, such as soaps or lotions?
My mother is unable to identify any clear inciting trigger for my symptoms.
How old are you, and do you have any other medical conditions or are you currently taking any medications?
I am 1-year-old, I am otherwise healthy, and I do not have any significant past medical history.
Final Diagnosis: Dyshidrotic Eczema
